com.linkedin.parseq

Class Tasks

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.linkedin.parseq.Tasks

  • public class Tasks
extends java.lang.Object
    This class provides a set of factory methods for create common Tasks.
    Author:
    Chris Pettitt (cpettitt@linkedin.com), Chi Chan (ckchan@linkedin.com)

      • action

        @Deprecated
public static Task<java.lang.Void> action(java.lang.String name,
                                                      java.lang.Runnable runnable)
        Deprecated. As of 2.0.0, replaced by Task.action
        Creates a new Task that have a value of type Void. Because the returned task has no value, it is typically used to produce side-effects.
        Parameters:
        name - a name that describes the action
        runnable - the action that will be executed when the task is run
        Returns:
        the new task
        See Also:
        Task.action

      • callable

        @Deprecated
public static <T> Task<T> callable(java.lang.String name,
                                               java.util.concurrent.Callable<? extends T> callable)
        Deprecated. As of 2.0.0, replaced by Task.callable
        Creates a new Task that's value will be set to the value returned from the supplied callable. This task is useful when doing basic computation that does not require asynchrony. It is not appropriate for long running or blocking tasks.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the return value for this task
        Parameters:
        name - a name that describes the action
        callable - the callable to execute when this task is run
        Returns:
        the new task
        See Also:
        Task.callable

      • seq

        @Deprecated
public static <T> Task<T> seq(Task<?> task1,
                                          Task<T> task2)
        Deprecated. As of 2.0.0, replaced by Task.map, Task.flatMap, Task.andThen and other methods in Task.
        Creates a new task that will run the given tasks sequentially (e.g. task1 will be finished before task2 starts). The value of the seq task will be the result of the last task in the sequence.
        See Also:
        Task.map, Task.flatMap, Task.andThen, Task

      • seq

        @Deprecated
public static <T> Task<T> seq(java.lang.Iterable<? extends Task<?>> tasks)
        Deprecated. As of 2.0.0, replaced by Task.map, Task.flatMap, Task.andThen and other methods in Task.
        Creates a new task that, when run, will run each of the supplied tasks in order. The value of this new task is the value of the last task in the sequence. This method is not type-safe.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the result value for the sequence of tasks
        Parameters:
        tasks - the tasks to run sequentially
        Returns:
        a new task that will run the given tasks sequentially
        See Also:
        Task.map, Task.flatMap, Task.andThen, Task

      • withSideEffect

        @Deprecated
public static <T> Task<T> withSideEffect(Task<T> parent,
                                                     Task<?> sideEffect)
        Deprecated. As of 2.0.0, replaced by Task.withSideEffect
        Creates a task that will run another task as a side effect once the primary task completes successfully. The side effect will not be run if the primary task fails or is canceled. The entire task is marked done once the base task completes, even if the side effect has not been run.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the result value of the parent task, and the resulting task.
        Parameters:
        parent - the primary task.
        sideEffect - the side effect of the primary task.
        Returns:
        a new task that will be done once parent completes, but has the given side effect.
        See Also:
        Task.withSideEffect

      • par

        @Deprecated
public static <T> ParTask<T> par(Task<? extends T> task1,
                                             Task<? extends T> task2)
        Deprecated. As of 2.0.0, replaced by Task.par
        Creates a new task that will run the given tasks in parallel (e.g. task1 can be executed at the same time as task2). When all tasks complete successfully, you can use Promise.get() to get a list of the results. If at least one task failed, then this task will also be marked as failed. Use ParTask.getTasks() or ParTask.getSuccessful() to get results in this case.
        See Also:
        Task.par

      • par

        public static <T> ParTask<T> par(java.lang.Iterable<? extends Task<? extends T>> tasks)
        Creates a new task that will run each of the supplied tasks in parallel (e.g. tasks[0] can be run at the same time as task2). This is a type-safe, collection-based alternative to vapar(Task[]).

        When all tasks complete successfully, you can use Promise.get() to get a list of the results. If at least one task failed, then this task will also be marked as failed. Use ParTask.getTasks() or ParTask.getSuccessful() to get results in this case.

        Parameters:
        tasks - the tasks to run in parallel
        Returns:
        The results of the tasks

      • timeoutWithError

        @Deprecated
public static <T> Task<T> timeoutWithError(long time,
                                                       java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit,
                                                       Task<T> task)
        Deprecated. As of 2.0.0, replaced by Task.withTimeout.
        Creates a new task that wraps the given task. If the given task finishes before the timeout occurs then this task takes on the value of the task. If the task does not complete in the given time then this task will have a TimeoutException. The wrapped task may be cancelled when a timeout occurs.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the value type for the task
        Parameters:
        time - the time to wait before timing out
        unit - the units for the time
        task - the task to wrap
        Returns:
        the new timeout task
        See Also:
        Task.withTimeout

      • timeoutWithError

        @Deprecated
public static <T> Task<T> timeoutWithError(java.lang.String name,
                                                       long time,
                                                       java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit,
                                                       Task<T> task)
        Deprecated. As of 2.0.0, replaced by Task.withTimeout.
        This method is similar to timeoutWithError(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit, Task), but it also takes a name that will be set on the returned task.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the value type for the task
        Parameters:
        name - the name of this task
        time - the time to wait before timing out
        unit - the units for the time
        task - the task to wrap
        Returns:
        the new timeout task
        See Also:
        Task.withTimeout
